did.unittitle: New York City Department of Parks reports
did.abstract: This collection contains two binders containing reports issued by the City of New York Department of Parks in 1950 and 1955 regarding renovation proposals and plans for various Brooklyn parks. The first report, titled Program of Post War Repairs, contains a list of needed improvements with associated costs for each park, while the second report, The Esplanade, Borough of Brooklyn: A Connecting Promenade Between Brighton Beach and Manhattan Beach Park, contains details on planning and legal authorization, correspondence, and photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains two binders containing reports issued by the City of New York Department of Parks in 1950 and 1955 regarding renovation proposals and plans for various Brooklyn parks. The first report, titled Program of Post War Repairs, contains a list of needed improvements with associated costs for each park, while the second report, The Esplanade, Borough of Brooklyn: A Connecting Promenade Between Brighton Beach and Manhattan Beach Park, contains details on planning and legal authorization, correspondence, and photographs.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The New York City Department of Parks was formed in 1934 when Mayor Fiorello H. LaGuardia discontinued the independent parks departments of the city's five boroughs and consolidated them to form a unifying administrative body to govern the entirety of the city's park system. LaGuardia appointed Robert Moses as the Parks Department's first commissioner. After becoming a branch of the Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration under Mayor John V. Lindsay in 1968, the Parks Department was reorganized as the Department of Parks & Recreation under Mayor Abraham D. Beame in 1976.
